S2Generator.excitation._interface module#

This module is used to build a unified interface for generating time series using various different incentives. It also manages the allocation of specific parameters for various data generation mechanisms.

Created on 2025/08/18 23:31:37 @author: Whenxuan Wang @email: wwhenxuan@gmail.com @url: wwhenxuan/S2Generator

class S2Generator.excitation._interface.Excitation(series_params: SeriesParams | None = None)[source]#

Bases: object

A unified interface for generating time series data is constructed through integrated parameter objects. A SeriesParams object is required for unified parameter control and management.

choice(rng: RandomState, input_dimension: int = 1) → ndarray[source]#

Randomly select n specific methods based on the probability of selecting each method for generating the stimulus time series data. n is input_dimension, which is the dimension of the generated time series data.

Param:

rng: The random number generator in NumPy with fixed seed.

Returns:

A numpy array of the random data generation methods.

property dtype: dtype#

Obtaining the data type of the time series data with different incentive methods.

generate(rng: RandomState, n_inputs_points: int, input_dimension: int | None = 1, normalization: str | None = None, return_choice: bool | None = False) → ndarray | Tuple[ndarray, List[Any] | ndarray][source]#

A unified interface for generating stimulus time series data.

This interface allows for random calls to time series generation methods such as MixedDistribution, AutoregressiveMovingAverage, ForecastPFN, KernelSynth, and IntrinsicModeFunction to construct stimulus time series data.

The selection of a particular method is achieved through random sampling. The probability of each method being sampled (selected) is a user-specified hyperparameter, as specified in the SeriesParams object.

Parameters:

  • rng – The random number generator in NumPy with fixed seed.

  • n_inputs_points – The length of time series data to be generated.

  • input_dimension – The dimension of time series data to be generated.

  • normalization – The normalization method to use, None for no normalization, choice in [“z-score”, “max-min”].

  • return_choice – If True, return a list of the selected methods.

Returns:

The generated time series data and the selected methods (Optional).

property prob_array: ndarray#

Obtaining the sampling probability of time series data with different incentive methods.

static create_autoregressive_params(rng: RandomState, p_order: int) → ndarray[source]#

Constructing the model parameters for the autoregressive process. Because the autoregressive process utilizes historical information accumulated in the time series, it can easily lead to numerical explosion in the generated stimulus time series. To ensure that the autoregressive process can stably generate a stationary time series, we impose certain constraints on the parameters of the autoregressive process.

  1. The absolute value of the last parameter (i.e., \(\varphi_p\)) is less than 1: \(|\varphi_p| < 1\)

  2. The sum of all parameters is less than 1: \(\varphi_1 + \varphi_2 + \dots + \varphi_p < 1\)

Parameters:

  • rng – The random number generator of NumPy with fixed seed.

  • p_order – The order of the autoregressive process.

Returns:

The autoregressive parameters.

S2Generator.excitation.base_excitation module#

This file is mainly used to build a unified stimulus time series generation interface module. We specify the general parameters of data generation through the abstract class. Then, we specify the generate method to generate specific data through the abstract method.

S2Generator.excitation.forecast_pfn module#

class S2Generator.excitation.forecast_pfn.ComponentNoise(k: float, median: float, scale: float)[source]#

Bases: object

Configures noise properties for time series generation.

Models multiplicative Weibull-distributed noise with scaling:

noise_term = (1 + scale * (weibull_noise - E[noise]))

Weibull distribution parameters:

k: Shape parameter (k > 0) median: Median value of the distribution

Special case:

scale = 0 → No noise (deterministic series)

__init__(k: float, median: float, scale: float) → None#
k: float#

Weibull shape parameter (k > 0)

median: float#

Median value of Weibull distribution

scale: float#

Noise scaling factor (0 = no noise)

class S2Generator.excitation.forecast_pfn.ComponentScale(base: float, linear: float | None = None, exp: float | None = None, a: ndarray | None = None, m: ndarray | None = None, w: ndarray | None = None, h: ndarray | None = None, minute: ndarray | None = None)[source]#

Bases: object

Represents scaling factors for time series components.

Each attribute controls the amplitude scaling of a specific temporal component: - base: Constant baseline scaling - linear: Linear trend scaling (slope) - exp: Exponential growth/decay factor - a: Annual seasonality scaling - m: Monthly seasonality scaling - w: Weekly seasonality scaling - h: Hourly seasonality scaling - minute: Minute-level seasonality scaling

Scaling formula:

component_value = base + linear*t + exp^t + a*annual + m*monthly + …

__init__(base: float, linear: float | None = None, exp: float | None = None, a: ndarray | None = None, m: ndarray | None = None, w: ndarray | None = None, h: ndarray | None = None, minute: ndarray | None = None) → None#
a: ndarray = None#

Annual seasonality scaling vector

base: float#

Constant baseline offset

exp: float = None#

Exponential growth/decay base (e.g., 1.01 for 1% growth)

h: ndarray = None#

Hourly seasonality scaling vector

linear: float = None#

Linear trend coefficient (slope)

m: ndarray = None#

Monthly seasonality scaling vector

minute: ndarray = None#

Minute-level seasonality scaling vector

w: ndarray = None#

Weekly seasonality scaling vector

class S2Generator.excitation.forecast_pfn.ForecastPFN(is_sub_day: bool | None = True, transition: bool | None = True, start_time: str | None = '1885-01-01', end_time: str | None = None, random_walk: bool = False, dtype: ~numpy.dtype = <class 'numpy.float64'>)[source]#

Bases: BaseExcitation

Generates excitation time series by simulating combinations of trends, seasonality, and noise.

This implementation is inspired by ForecastPFN: Synthetically-Trained Zero-Shot Forecasting (https://arxiv.org/abs/2311.01933) with significant enhancements: 1. Unified data generation interface 2. Extended hyperparameter configuration 3. Flexible temporal component weighting 4. Improved time range handling 5. Customizable frequency components

Key innovations over the original implementation: - Support for sub-daily frequencies - Configurable transition behaviors - Component-specific scaling/offset/noise - Random walk option for non-stationary series

__init__(is_sub_day: bool | None = True, transition: bool | None = True, start_time: str | None = '1885-01-01', end_time: str | None = None, random_walk: bool = False, dtype: ~numpy.dtype = <class 'numpy.float64'>) → None[source]#

Initializes the time series generator with configuration parameters.

Parameters:

  • is_sub_day (Optional[bool]) – Enable sub-daily frequency components (minutes/hours)

  • transition (Optional[bool]) – Enable smooth transitions between frequency components

  • start_time (Optional[str]) – Start timestamp for generated series (ISO format: YYYY-MM-DD)

  • end_time (Optional[str]) – End timestamp for generated series. Uses current date if None.

  • random_walk (bool) – Enable random walk transformation for non-stationary series

  • dtype (np.dtype) – Numerical precision for output series

property annual: float | ndarray#

Annual seasonality component weight(s)

generate(rng: RandomState, n_inputs_points: int = 512, input_dimension: int = 1, freq_index: int | None = None, start: Timestamp | None = None, options: Dict | None = None, random_walk: bool | None = None) → ndarray[source]#

Generates time series using the ForecastPFN algorithm.

Implementation based on: ForecastPFN: Synthetically-Trained Zero-Shot Forecasting (https://arxiv.org/abs/2311.01933)

The algorithm combines: 1. Multiple seasonal components (annual, monthly, weekly, etc.) 2. Trend components (linear, exponential) 3. Noise components (Weibull-distributed) 4. Optional random walk transformation

Parameters:

  • rng – Seeded random number generator for reproducibility.

  • n_inputs_points – Number of time points to generate per dimension

  • input_dimension – Number of independent time series dimensions to generate

  • freq_index – Index of frequency configuration to use (0-4 for sub-daily)

  • start – Custom start timestamp for the series. Uses class default if None.

  • options – Additional generation options (reserved for future extensions)

  • random_walk – Enable random walk transformation. Overrides class default.

Returns:

Generated time series array of shape (n_inputs_points, input_dimension)

generate_series(rng: RandomState, length=100, freq_index: int | None = None, start: Timestamp | None = None, options: dict | None = None, random_walk: bool = False) → Dict[str, Series | ndarray | DataFrame | DatetimeIndex][source]#

Function to construct synthetic series configs and generate synthetic series.

Parameters:

  • rng – The random number generator in NumPy with fixed seed.

  • length – The length of time series to generate.

  • freq_index – The frequency of time series to generate.

  • start – The start date of time series to generate.

  • options – Options dict for generating series.

  • random_walk – Whether to generate random walk or not.

Returns:

The generated series dict.

static get_component_noise_config(k: float, median: float, scale: float) → ComponentNoise[source]#

Creates noise configuration for time series generation.

Parameters define multiplicative Weibull-distributed noise: :param k: Shape parameter for Weibull distribution (k > 0).

  • k < 1: Decreasing failure rate

  • k = 1: Exponential distribution (constant failure rate)

  • k > 1: Increasing failure rate

Parameters:

  • median (float) – Median value of Weibull distribution (location parameter)

  • scale (float) –

    Noise scaling factor where:

    • 0 = no noise (deterministic series)

    • 0-0.1 = low noise

    • 0.1-0.5 = moderate noise

    • >0.5 = high noise

Returns:

Noise configuration object

Return type:

ComponentNoise

Note:

These parameters could be set as class attributes for consistency

get_component_scale_config(base: float, linear: float | None = None, exp: float | None = None, annual: ndarray | None = None, monthly: ndarray | None = None, weekly: ndarray | None = None, hourly: ndarray | None = None, minutely: ndarray | None = None) → ComponentScale[source]#

Creates scaling configuration for time series components.

This function follows the ForecastPFN architecture to define amplitude scaling: 1. Uses class-level component weights as defaults when parameters are None 2. Allows custom override of specific components 3. Handles both fundamental (base, linear, exp) and seasonal components

Parameters:

  • base (float) – Constant baseline scaling factor

  • linear (Optional[float]) – Linear trend coefficient (slope). Default: class-stored value

  • exp (Optional[float]) – Exponential growth/decay base. Default: class-stored value

  • annual (Optional[np.ndarray]) – Annual seasonality scaling vector. Default: self._annual

  • monthly (Optional[np.ndarray]) – Monthly seasonality scaling vector. Default: self._monthly

  • weekly (Optional[np.ndarray]) – Weekly seasonality scaling vector. Default: self._weekly

  • hourly (Optional[np.ndarray]) – Hourly seasonality scaling vector. Default: self._hourly

  • minutely (Optional[np.ndarray]) – Minute-level seasonality scaling vector. Default: self._minutely

Returns:

Component scaling configuration

Return type:

ComponentScale

Note:

The base, linear, and exp parameters could be moved to class attributes

get_time_series_config(scale_config: ComponentScale | None = None, offset_config: ComponentScale | None = None, noise_config: ComponentNoise | None = None) → SeriesConfig[source]#

Creates comprehensive configuration for time series generation.

Combines three essential aspects of time series modeling: 1. Scale: Component amplitude scaling 2. Offset: Baseline offsets 3. Noise: Stochastic properties

Uses class-stored configurations when parameters are None.

Parameters:

  • offset_config (Optional[ComponentScale]) – Baseline offset configuration. Default: self._offset_config

  • noise_config (Optional[ComponentNoise]) – Noise generation parameters. Default: self._noise_config

Returns:

Complete series generation configuration

Return type:

SeriesConfig

set_freq_variables(is_sub_day: bool | None = None) → None[source]#

Configures frequency components based on temporal resolution.

For sub-daily series (is_sub_day=True):

  • Includes minute, hourly, daily, weekly, monthly components

  • Excludes yearly components for stability

For daily+ series (is_sub_day=False):

  • Includes daily, weekly, monthly components

Parameters:

is_sub_day (Optional[bool]) – Enable sub-daily components. Uses class default if None.

set_frequency_components(rng: RandomState, frequency: str) → None[source]#

Configures frequency component weights based on input frequency type.

Sets randomized component weights optimized for different temporal patterns: - min: Optimized for minute-level data (high minute variation, low hourly) - h: Optimized for hourly data (low minute variation, high hourly) - D: Optimized for daily data (high weekly seasonality, low monthly) - W: Optimized for weekly data (balanced monthly/annual seasonality) - MS: Optimized for monthly starts (low weekly, moderate annual seasonality) - YE: Optimized for year-end data (low weekly, high annual seasonality)

Note: Weight ranges are empirically determined and can be modified as class properties.

Parameters:

  • rng – The random number generator in NumPy with fixed seed.

  • frequency (str) – Temporal frequency identifier specifying the data type

Raises:

NotImplementedError – For unsupported frequency identifiers

set_transition(transition: bool) → None[source]#

Enables/disables smooth transitions between frequency components.

When enabled, creates gradual changes between seasonal patterns rather than abrupt shifts. Particularly useful for simulating business cycles or economic regime changes.

Parameters:

transition (bool) – Enable component transition smoothing.

class S2Generator.excitation.forecast_pfn.SeriesConfig(scale: ComponentScale, offset: ComponentScale, noise_config: ComponentNoise)[source]#

Bases: object

Comprehensive configuration for time series generation.

Combines: 1. scale: Amplitude scaling components (ComponentScale) 2. offset: Baseline offset components (ComponentScale) 3. noise_config: Stochastic noise parameters (ComponentNoise)

The string representation encodes key parameters in compact format:

“L{linear}E{exp}A{annual}M{monthly}W{weekly}”

  • Linear (L): 1000 × linear

  • Exponential (E): 10000 × (exp - 1)

  • Annual (A): 100 × annual_scale

  • Monthly (M): 100 × monthly_scale

  • Weekly (W): 100 × weekly_scale

__init__(scale: ComponentScale, offset: ComponentScale, noise_config: ComponentNoise) → None#
noise_config: ComponentNoise#

Noise generation configuration

offset: ComponentScale#

Baseline offset configuration

scale: ComponentScale#

Amplitude scaling configuration

S2Generator.excitation.forecast_pfn.get_freq_component(rng: RandomState, dates_feature: Index, n_harmonics: int | float, n_total: int | float) → ndarray | Any[source]#

Method to get systematic movement of values across time :param dates_feature: the component of date to be used for generating the seasonal movement is different. For example, for monthly patterns in a year we will use months of a date, while for day-wise patterns in a month, we will use days as the feature

Parameters:

  • rng – The random number generator in NumPy with fixed seed.

  • n_harmonics – number of harmonics to include. For example, for monthly trend, we use 12/2 = 6 harmonics

  • n_total – total cycle length

Returns:

numpy array of shape dates_feature.shape containing

sinusoidal value for a given point in time

S2Generator.excitation.forecast_pfn.get_random_walk_series(rng: RandomState, length: int, movements: List[int] | None = None)[source]#

Function to generate a random walk series with a specified length. This is a random process model widely used in finance, physics, statistics and other fields.

Parameters:

  • rng – Random number generator used to generate random values.

  • length – Shape parameter, determines the shape of the distribution:

  • movements – Shape parameter, possible step sizes: 1. Default: Binary Random Walk (±1); 2. Customizable (e.g., [-2, 0, 2]).

Returns:

pd.DatetimeIndex containing the random walk series.

S2Generator.excitation.forecast_pfn.get_transition_coefficients(context_length: int) → ndarray[source]#

Transition series refers to the linear combination of 2 series S1 and S2 such that the series S represents S1 for a period and S2 for the remaining period. We model S as S = (1 - f) * S1 + f * S2 Here f = 1 / (1 + e^{-k (x-m)}) where m = (a + b) / 2 and k is chosen such that f(a) = 0.1 (and hence f(b) = 0.9). a and b refer to 0.2 * CONTEXT_LENGTH and 0.8 * CONTEXT_LENGTH

Param:

context_length: The length of time series to be generated.

Returns:

np.ndarray of transition coefficients.

S2Generator.excitation.forecast_pfn.weibull_noise(rng: RandomState, k: float | None = 2, length: int | None = 1, median: float | None = 1) → ndarray[source]#

Function to generate weibull noise with a fixed median. Its main feature is that it achieves a fixed median output by adjusting the scale parameter. The probability density function of the Weibull distribution is: f(x; λ, k) = (k/λ)(x/λ)^{k-1}e^{-(x/λ)^k} for x ≥ 0 To achieve a fixed median, the function inversely solves for the scale parameter λ using the median formula: lamda = median / (np.log(2) ** (1 / k))

Parameters:

  • rng – Random number generator used to generate random values.

  • k – Shape parameter, determines the shape of the distribution: 1. k < 1: Decreasing failure rate; 2. k = 1: Exponential distribution; 3. k > 1: Increasing failure rate.

  • length – Shape parameter, determines the shape of the distribution:

  • median – Mandatory median (50% quantile).

Returns:

S2Generator.excitation.intrinsic_mode_functions module#

class S2Generator.excitation.intrinsic_mode_functions.IntrinsicModeFunction(min_base_imfs: int = 2, max_base_imfs: int = 4, min_choice_imfs: int = 1, max_choice_imfs: int = 5, probability_dict: ~typing.Dict[str, float] | None = None, probability_list: ~typing.List[float] | None = None, min_duration: float = 0.5, max_duration: float = 10.0, min_amplitude: float = 0.01, max_amplitude: float = 10.0, min_frequency: float = 0.01, max_frequency: float = 8.0, noise_level: float = 0.1, upper_energy: float | None = 32, dtype: ~numpy.dtype = <class 'numpy.float64'>)[source]#

Bases: BaseExcitation

Generates excitation time series in the form of Intrinsic Mode Functions (IntrinsicModeFunction).

This class creates composite signals by combining fundamental waveform components through Empirical Mode Decomposition (EMD)-like synthesis. The generated signals can simulate various real-world vibration patterns and non-stationary behaviors.

See More Information please visit PySDKit: A Python library for signal decomposition algorithms. wwhenxuan/PySDKit

__init__(min_base_imfs: int = 2, max_base_imfs: int = 4, min_choice_imfs: int = 1, max_choice_imfs: int = 5, probability_dict: ~typing.Dict[str, float] | None = None, probability_list: ~typing.List[float] | None = None, min_duration: float = 0.5, max_duration: float = 10.0, min_amplitude: float = 0.01, max_amplitude: float = 10.0, min_frequency: float = 0.01, max_frequency: float = 8.0, noise_level: float = 0.1, upper_energy: float | None = 32, dtype: ~numpy.dtype = <class 'numpy.float64'>) → None[source]#

Initializes the IMF signal generator with configuration parameters.

Parameters:

  • min_base_imfs (int) – Minimum number of fundamental IMF components to generate

  • max_base_imfs (int) – Maximum number of fundamental IMF components to generate

  • min_choice_imfs (int) – Minimum number of IntrinsicModeFunction to select from available types

  • max_choice_imfs (int) – Maximum number of IntrinsicModeFunction to select from available types

  • probability_dict (Optional[Dict[str, float]]) – Custom probability distribution for IMF types, with keys matching available IMF names

  • probability_list (Optional[List[float]]) – Custom probability weights for IMF types in predefined order (overrides probability_dict)

  • min_duration (float) – Minimum signal duration in seconds

  • max_duration (float) – Maximum signal duration in seconds

  • min_amplitude (float) – Minimum amplitude for generated signal components

  • max_amplitude (float) – Maximum amplitude for generated signal components

  • min_frequency (float) – Minimum frequency for signal components (Hz)

  • max_frequency (float) – Maximum frequency for signal components (Hz)

  • noise_level (float) – Amplitude of Gaussian noise to add (relative to signal amplitude)

  • upper_energy – The upper energy of the generated signal.

  • dtype (np.dtype) – Numerical precision for generated signals

generate(rng: RandomState, n_inputs_points: int = 512, input_dimension: int = 1) → ndarray[source]#

Generates multi-dimensional time series through IMF composition.

Signal synthesis pipeline for each dimension: 1. Initialize zero matrix 2. Add fundamental waveform components (sine/cosine) 3. Add randomly selected IMF components 4. Add energy-adaptive Gaussian noise

Parameters:

  • rng (np.random.RandomState) – Seeded random number generator

  • n_inputs_points (int) – Number of time samples per dimension

  • input_dimension (int) – Number of output dimensions (channels)

Returns:

Generated time series array of shape (n_inputs_points, input_dimension)

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_base_imfs(imfs: ndarray, rng: RandomState, n_inputs_points: int) → ndarray[source]#

Generates fundamental IMF components (sine/cosine) and adds to the signal.

The base IMFs form the core waveform structure:

  1. Randomly selects number of base components (between min_base_imfs and max_base_imfs)

  2. For each component:

    • Randomly selects waveform type (sine/cosine with equal probability)

    • Generates random amplitude, frequency, and duration

    • Computes adaptive sampling rate for time alignment

    • Adds component to the signal matrix

Parameters:

  • imfs (np.ndarray) – Target signal matrix to populate with IMFs

  • rng (np.random.RandomState) – Seeded random number generator for reproducibility

  • n_inputs_points (int) – Required number of time samples

Returns:

Signal matrix with added fundamental components

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_choice_imfs(imfs: ndarray, rng: RandomState, n_inputs_points: int) → ndarray[source]#

Adds randomly selected IMF components from available types.

Handles special case for AM signals which require additional parameters: 1. Randomly selects number of components (between min_choice_imfs and max_choice_imfs) 2. For each component:

  • Selects IMF type based on configured probability distribution

  • Generates random amplitude, frequency, and duration

  • For AM signals: generates random modulation parameters

  • For other signals: uses standard parameters

  • Adds component to signal matrix

Parameters:

  • imfs (np.ndarray) – Target signal matrix being constructed

  • rng (np.random.RandomState) – Seeded random number generator

  • n_inputs_points (int) – Required number of time samples

Returns:

Signal matrix with added selected components

Return type:

np.ndarray

S2Generator.excitation.kernel_synth.get_exp_sine_squared(length: int | None = 256) → List[Kernel][source]#

Creates periodic kernels with various temporal patterns for time series modeling.

Generates ExpSineSquared kernels covering multiple time frequencies: - Hourly (H), Half-hourly (0.5H), Quarter-hourly (0.25H) - Daily (D), Half-day (0.5D) - Weekly (W) - Monthly (M) - Quarterly (Q) - Yearly (Y)

Periodicity parameters are scaled by input length to maintain consistent temporal relationships across different time series lengths.

Parameters:

length (Optional[int]) – Reference length for periodicity scaling. Default assumes 256 time points.

Returns:

List of periodic kernels with diverse temporal patterns

Return type:

List[Kernel]

S2Generator.excitation.kernel_synth.get_rational_quadratic(length: int | None = 256) → List[Kernel][source]#

Creates Rational Quadratic kernels modeling multi-scale variations.

Combines characteristics of multiple RBF kernels: k(x_i, x_j) = (1 + ||x_i - x_j||²/(2αl²))^(-α)

Parameters:

length (Optional[int]) – Unused parameter (maintained for interface consistency)

Draw a sample from a GP prior. An efficient version that allows specification of the sampling method. The default sampling method used in GaussianProcessRegressor is based on SVD which is significantly slower that alternatives such as eigh and cholesky.

S2Generator.excitation.mixed_distribution module#

This module generates excitation time series data from a mixture of multiple Gaussian or uniform distributions. This module was subsequently integrated into the Excitation module as an interface. In [examples](wwhenxuan/S2Generator), we provide examples demonstrating the module’s usage.

generate_stats(rng: RandomState, input_dimension: int, n_centroids: int) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, List[ndarray]][source]#

Generate parameters required for sampling from a mixture distribution.

Parameters:

  • rng – The random number generator in NumPy with fixed seed.

  • input_dimension – The number of input dimension.

  • n_centroids – The number of centroids in mixed distribution.

Returns:

  • means: Mean array with np.ndarray;

  • covariances: Covariance array (Note: This actually generates variances,

    as each center generates a separate variance value in each dimension, so the covariance matrix is a diagonal matrix);

  • rotations: Rotation matrix list (each element is a np.ndarray, representing the rotation matrix for each center);

Module contents#

This module is used to generate stimulus time series data for input into complex systems (symbolic expressions). It primarily includes five different generation methods:

  • [MixedDistribution](wwhenxuan/S2Generator);

  • [AutoregressiveMovingAverage](wwhenxuan/S2Generator);

  • [ForecastPFN](wwhenxuan/S2Generator);

  • [KernelSynth](wwhenxuan/S2Generator);

  • [IntrinsicModeFunction](wwhenxuan/S2Generator);

Detailed hyperparameter configuration is provided for each method. Each method can also generate time series data by passing a random number generator to the __call__ method or the generate method.

To ensure unified calling, we further encapsulate these five methods into Excitation, and provide a unified SeriesParams object for parameter management.

Created on 2025/08/13 23:47:59 @author: Whenxuan Wang @email: wwhenxuan@gmail.com @url: wwhenxuan/S2Generator

class S2Generator.excitation.AutoregressiveMovingAverage(p_min: int | None = 1, p_max: int | None = 3, q_min: int | None = 1, q_max: int | None = 5, upper_bound: float = 512, dtype: ~numpy.dtype = <class 'numpy.float64'>)[source]#

Bases: BaseExcitation

Generate motivating time series data by constructing random parameterized moving average and autoregressive.

arma_series(rng: RandomState, time_series: ndarray, p_params: ndarray | None = None, q_params: ndarray | None = None) → ndarray[source]#

Generate an ARMA process based on the specified parameters.

Parameters:

  • rng – Random number generator of NumPy with fixed seed.

  • time_series – The zeros time series.

  • p_params – The parameters of the AR(p) process.

  • q_params – The parameters of the MA(q) process.

static create_autoregressive_params(rng: RandomState, p_order: int) → ndarray[source]#

Constructing the model parameters for the autoregressive process. Because the autoregressive process utilizes historical information accumulated in the time series, it can easily lead to numerical explosion in the generated stimulus time series. To ensure that the autoregressive process can stably generate a stationary time series, we impose certain constraints on the parameters of the autoregressive process.

  1. The absolute value of the last parameter (i.e., \(\varphi_p\)) is less than 1: \(|\varphi_p| < 1\)

  2. The sum of all parameters is less than 1: \(\varphi_1 + \varphi_2 + \dots + \varphi_p < 1\)

Parameters:

  • rng – The random number generator of NumPy with fixed seed.

  • p_order – The order of the autoregressive process.

Returns:

The autoregressive parameters.

create_sampling_dict(series_params: SeriesParams | None = None) → Dict[str, MixedDistribution | AutoregressiveMovingAverage | ForecastPFN | KernelSynth | IntrinsicModeFunction][source]#

property dtype: dtype#

Obtaining the data type of the time series data with different incentive methods.

generate(rng: RandomState, n_inputs_points: int, input_dimension: int | None = 1, normalization: str | None = None, return_choice: bool | None = False) → ndarray | Tuple[ndarray, List[Any] | ndarray][source]#

A unified interface for generating stimulus time series data.

This interface allows for random calls to time series generation methods such as MixedDistribution, AutoregressiveMovingAverage, ForecastPFN, KernelSynth, and IntrinsicModeFunction to construct stimulus time series data.

The selection of a particular method is achieved through random sampling. The probability of each method being sampled (selected) is a user-specified hyperparameter, as specified in the SeriesParams object.

Parameters:

  • rng – The random number generator in NumPy with fixed seed.

  • n_inputs_points – The length of time series data to be generated.

  • input_dimension – The dimension of time series data to be generated.

  • normalization – The normalization method to use, None for no normalization, choice in [“z-score”, “max-min”].

  • return_choice – If True, return a list of the selected methods.

Returns:

The generated time series data and the selected methods (Optional).

property prob_array: ndarray#

Obtaining the sampling probability of time series data with different incentive methods.

property sampling_dict: Dict[str, MixedDistribution | AutoregressiveMovingAverage | ForecastPFN | KernelSynth | IntrinsicModeFunction]#

class S2Generator.excitation.ForecastPFN(is_sub_day: bool | None = True, transition: bool | None = True, start_time: str | None = '1885-01-01', end_time: str | None = None, random_walk: bool = False, dtype: ~numpy.dtype = <class 'numpy.float64'>)[source]#

Bases: BaseExcitation

Generates excitation time series by simulating combinations of trends, seasonality, and noise.

This implementation is inspired by ForecastPFN: Synthetically-Trained Zero-Shot Forecasting (https://arxiv.org/abs/2311.01933) with significant enhancements: 1. Unified data generation interface 2. Extended hyperparameter configuration 3. Flexible temporal component weighting 4. Improved time range handling 5. Customizable frequency components

Key innovations over the original implementation: - Support for sub-daily frequencies - Configurable transition behaviors - Component-specific scaling/offset/noise - Random walk option for non-stationary series

property annual: float | ndarray#

Annual seasonality component weight(s)

generate(rng: RandomState, n_inputs_points: int = 512, input_dimension: int = 1, freq_index: int | None = None, start: Timestamp | None = None, options: Dict | None = None, random_walk: bool | None = None) → ndarray[source]#

Generates time series using the ForecastPFN algorithm.

Implementation based on: ForecastPFN: Synthetically-Trained Zero-Shot Forecasting (https://arxiv.org/abs/2311.01933)

The algorithm combines: 1. Multiple seasonal components (annual, monthly, weekly, etc.) 2. Trend components (linear, exponential) 3. Noise components (Weibull-distributed) 4. Optional random walk transformation

Parameters:

  • rng – Seeded random number generator for reproducibility.

  • n_inputs_points – Number of time points to generate per dimension

  • input_dimension – Number of independent time series dimensions to generate

  • freq_index – Index of frequency configuration to use (0-4 for sub-daily)

  • start – Custom start timestamp for the series. Uses class default if None.

  • options – Additional generation options (reserved for future extensions)

  • random_walk – Enable random walk transformation. Overrides class default.

Returns:

Generated time series array of shape (n_inputs_points, input_dimension)

generate_series(rng: RandomState, length=100, freq_index: int | None = None, start: Timestamp | None = None, options: dict | None = None, random_walk: bool = False) → Dict[str, Series | ndarray | DataFrame | DatetimeIndex][source]#

Function to construct synthetic series configs and generate synthetic series.

Parameters:

  • rng – The random number generator in NumPy with fixed seed.

  • length – The length of time series to generate.

  • freq_index – The frequency of time series to generate.

  • start – The start date of time series to generate.

  • options – Options dict for generating series.

  • random_walk – Whether to generate random walk or not.

Returns:

The generated series dict.

static get_component_noise_config(k: float, median: float, scale: float) → ComponentNoise[source]#

Creates noise configuration for time series generation.

Parameters define multiplicative Weibull-distributed noise: :param k: Shape parameter for Weibull distribution (k > 0).

  • k < 1: Decreasing failure rate

  • k = 1: Exponential distribution (constant failure rate)

  • k > 1: Increasing failure rate

Parameters:

  • median (float) – Median value of Weibull distribution (location parameter)

  • scale (float) –

    Noise scaling factor where:

    • 0 = no noise (deterministic series)

    • 0-0.1 = low noise

    • 0.1-0.5 = moderate noise

    • >0.5 = high noise

Returns:

Noise configuration object

Return type:

ComponentNoise

Note:

These parameters could be set as class attributes for consistency

get_component_scale_config(base: float, linear: float | None = None, exp: float | None = None, annual: ndarray | None = None, monthly: ndarray | None = None, weekly: ndarray | None = None, hourly: ndarray | None = None, minutely: ndarray | None = None) → ComponentScale[source]#

Creates scaling configuration for time series components.

This function follows the ForecastPFN architecture to define amplitude scaling: 1. Uses class-level component weights as defaults when parameters are None 2. Allows custom override of specific components 3. Handles both fundamental (base, linear, exp) and seasonal components

Parameters:

  • base (float) – Constant baseline scaling factor

  • linear (Optional[float]) – Linear trend coefficient (slope). Default: class-stored value

  • exp (Optional[float]) – Exponential growth/decay base. Default: class-stored value

  • annual (Optional[np.ndarray]) – Annual seasonality scaling vector. Default: self._annual

  • monthly (Optional[np.ndarray]) – Monthly seasonality scaling vector. Default: self._monthly

  • weekly (Optional[np.ndarray]) – Weekly seasonality scaling vector. Default: self._weekly

  • hourly (Optional[np.ndarray]) – Hourly seasonality scaling vector. Default: self._hourly

  • minutely (Optional[np.ndarray]) – Minute-level seasonality scaling vector. Default: self._minutely

Returns:

Component scaling configuration

Return type:

ComponentScale

Note:

The base, linear, and exp parameters could be moved to class attributes

get_time_series_config(scale_config: ComponentScale | None = None, offset_config: ComponentScale | None = None, noise_config: ComponentNoise | None = None) → SeriesConfig[source]#

Creates comprehensive configuration for time series generation.

Combines three essential aspects of time series modeling: 1. Scale: Component amplitude scaling 2. Offset: Baseline offsets 3. Noise: Stochastic properties

Uses class-stored configurations when parameters are None.

Parameters:

  • scale_config (Optional[ComponentScale]) – Amplitude scaling configuration. Default: self._scale_config

  • offset_config (Optional[ComponentScale]) – Baseline offset configuration. Default: self._offset_config

  • noise_config (Optional[ComponentNoise]) – Noise generation parameters. Default: self._noise_config

Returns:

Complete series generation configuration

Return type:

SeriesConfig

set_freq_variables(is_sub_day: bool | None = None) → None[source]#

Configures frequency components based on temporal resolution.

For sub-daily series (is_sub_day=True):

  • Includes minute, hourly, daily, weekly, monthly components

  • Excludes yearly components for stability

For daily+ series (is_sub_day=False):

  • Includes daily, weekly, monthly components

Parameters:

is_sub_day (Optional[bool]) – Enable sub-daily components. Uses class default if None.

set_frequency_components(rng: RandomState, frequency: str) → None[source]#

Configures frequency component weights based on input frequency type.

Sets randomized component weights optimized for different temporal patterns: - min: Optimized for minute-level data (high minute variation, low hourly) - h: Optimized for hourly data (low minute variation, high hourly) - D: Optimized for daily data (high weekly seasonality, low monthly) - W: Optimized for weekly data (balanced monthly/annual seasonality) - MS: Optimized for monthly starts (low weekly, moderate annual seasonality) - YE: Optimized for year-end data (low weekly, high annual seasonality)

Note: Weight ranges are empirically determined and can be modified as class properties.

Parameters:

  • rng – The random number generator in NumPy with fixed seed.

  • frequency (str) – Temporal frequency identifier specifying the data type

Raises:

NotImplementedError – For unsupported frequency identifiers

set_transition(transition: bool) → None[source]#

Enables/disables smooth transitions between frequency components.

When enabled, creates gradual changes between seasonal patterns rather than abrupt shifts. Particularly useful for simulating business cycles or economic regime changes.

Parameters:

transition (bool) – Enable component transition smoothing.

class S2Generator.excitation.IntrinsicModeFunction(min_base_imfs: int = 2, max_base_imfs: int = 4, min_choice_imfs: int = 1, max_choice_imfs: int = 5, probability_dict: ~typing.Dict[str, float] | None = None, probability_list: ~typing.List[float] | None = None, min_duration: float = 0.5, max_duration: float = 10.0, min_amplitude: float = 0.01, max_amplitude: float = 10.0, min_frequency: float = 0.01, max_frequency: float = 8.0, noise_level: float = 0.1, upper_energy: float | None = 32, dtype: ~numpy.dtype = <class 'numpy.float64'>)[source]#

Bases: BaseExcitation

Generates excitation time series in the form of Intrinsic Mode Functions (IntrinsicModeFunction).

This class creates composite signals by combining fundamental waveform components through Empirical Mode Decomposition (EMD)-like synthesis. The generated signals can simulate various real-world vibration patterns and non-stationary behaviors.

See More Information please visit PySDKit: A Python library for signal decomposition algorithms. wwhenxuan/PySDKit

adjust_upper_energy(signal: ndarray, rng: RandomState) → ndarray[source]#

Adjusts the upper energy of the signal. This operation is mainly used when the amplitude of the time series data generated by the method is too large.

Parameters:

  • signal – Signal with high energy to be adjusted.

  • rng – The random number generator in NumPy with fixed seed.

Returns:

The adjusted signal with the lower energy.

generate(rng: RandomState, n_inputs_points: int = 512, input_dimension: int = 1) → ndarray[source]#

Generates multi-dimensional time series through IMF composition.

Signal synthesis pipeline for each dimension: 1. Initialize zero matrix 2. Add fundamental waveform components (sine/cosine) 3. Add randomly selected IMF components 4. Add energy-adaptive Gaussian noise

Parameters:

  • rng (np.random.RandomState) – Seeded random number generator

  • n_inputs_points (int) – Number of time samples per dimension

  • input_dimension (int) – Number of output dimensions (channels)

Returns:

Generated time series array of shape (n_inputs_points, input_dimension)

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_base_imfs(imfs: ndarray, rng: RandomState, n_inputs_points: int) → ndarray[source]#

Generates fundamental IMF components (sine/cosine) and adds to the signal.

The base IMFs form the core waveform structure:

  1. Randomly selects number of base components (between min_base_imfs and max_base_imfs)

  2. For each component:

    • Randomly selects waveform type (sine/cosine with equal probability)

    • Generates random amplitude, frequency, and duration

    • Computes adaptive sampling rate for time alignment

    • Adds component to the signal matrix

Parameters:

  • imfs (np.ndarray) – Target signal matrix to populate with IMFs

  • rng (np.random.RandomState) – Seeded random number generator for reproducibility

  • n_inputs_points (int) – Required number of time samples

Returns:

Signal matrix with added fundamental components

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_choice_imfs(imfs: ndarray, rng: RandomState, n_inputs_points: int) → ndarray[source]#

Adds randomly selected IMF components from available types.

Handles special case for AM signals which require additional parameters: 1. Randomly selects number of components (between min_choice_imfs and max_choice_imfs) 2. For each component:

  • Selects IMF type based on configured probability distribution

  • Generates random amplitude, frequency, and duration

  • For AM signals: generates random modulation parameters

  • For other signals: uses standard parameters

  • Adds component to signal matrix

Parameters:

  • imfs (np.ndarray) – Target signal matrix being constructed

  • rng (np.random.RandomState) – Seeded random number generator

  • n_inputs_points (int) – Required number of time samples

Returns:

Signal matrix with added selected components

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_random_amplitude(rng: RandomState, number: int) → ndarray[source]#

Generates random amplitudes for IMF components.

Amplitudes are uniformly distributed between min_amplitude and max_amplitude.

Parameters:

  • rng (np.random.RandomState) – Seeded random number generator

  • number (int) – Count of amplitudes to generate

Returns:

Array of amplitude values

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_random_duration(rng: RandomState, number: int) → ndarray[source]#

Generates random durations for IMF components.

Durations are uniformly distributed between min_duration and max_duration.

Parameters:

  • rng (np.random.RandomState) – Seeded random number generator for reproducibility

  • number (int) – Count of durations to generate (matches IMF count)

Returns:

Array of durations in seconds

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_random_frequency(rng: RandomState, number: int) → ndarray[source]#

Generates random frequencies for IMF components.

Frequencies are uniformly distributed between min_frequency and max_frequency.

Parameters:

  • rng (np.random.RandomState) – Seeded random number generator

  • number (int) – Count of frequencies to generate

Returns:

Array of frequency values in Hz

generate_stats(rng: RandomState, input_dimension: int, n_centroids: int) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, List[ndarray]][source]#

Generate parameters required for sampling from a mixture distribution.

Parameters:

  • rng – The random number generator in NumPy with fixed seed.

  • input_dimension – The number of input dimension.

  • n_centroids – The number of centroids in mixed distribution.

Returns:

  • means: Mean array with np.ndarray;

  • covariances: Covariance array (Note: This actually generates variances,

    as each center generates a separate variance value in each dimension, so the covariance matrix is a diagonal matrix);

  • rotations: Rotation matrix list (each element is a np.ndarray, representing the rotation matrix for each center);

generate_uniform(rng: RandomState, input_dimension: int, n_centroids: int, n_points_comp: ndarray) → ndarray[source]#

Generate time series of specified dimensions and lengths using a uniform mixture distribution.

Parameters:

  • rng – The random number generator in NumPy with fixed seed.

  • input_dimension – The number of input dimension.

  • n_centroids – The number of centroids in mixed distribution.

  • n_points_comp – The number of points in each dimension.

Returns:

Time series of specified dimensions and lengths.
